content: The Act is titled the "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms such as Administration, Administrator, air carrier, appropriate congressional committees, and foreign air carrier. The "Aviation Employee Screening and Security Enhancement Act of 2017" defines key terms related to aviation security, including foreign air carrier, intelligence community, secured area, Security Identification Display Area, and sterile area. SEC. 3. COST AND FEASIBILITY STUDY. The Administrator must conduct a cost and feasibility study on implementing enhanced security measures at various airports, including secure doors with card or biometric entry, surveillance video recording, and advanced screening technologies. The study required under subsection (a) shall include information related to the employee screening costs of airports that have implemented practices of screening all employees accessing secured areas, including costs of entry and exit points and cost-effectiveness comparisons. The study will assess costs and effectiveness of security features for employee entry and exit points at airports, with the Comptroller General reviewing the study for quality and reliability. The report will be submitted to the Committee on Homeland Security. The Comptroller General will report to relevant committees on the results of the review of security features at airport entry and exit points. SEC. 4. AIRPORT WORKER EDUCATION AND SECURITY AWARENESS. The Administrator will collaborate with various stakeholders to enhance security awareness among airport workers regarding insider threats and access controls. Additionally, credentialing standards will be assessed to ensure security practices are in place. The Administrator, along with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee, will assess credentialing standards and practices to address insider threats in aviation security. A report on the assessment results must be submitted to congressional committees within 30 days. Airport operators will be required to submit social security numbers for individuals applying for access to the Security Identification Display Area within 60 days of the Act's enactment to enhance security vetting effectiveness. To strengthen security vetting, applicants for access to a Security Identification Display Area must provide their social security number. Airport operators must include a screening notice in applications for access, informing applicants that they may be screened at any time while in the area. SEC. 5. SECURING AIRPORT WORKER ACCESS. The Administrator will collaborate with airport operators and the Aviation Security Advisory Committee to identify advanced technologies, including biometric identification, for securing employee access to airport secured and sterile areas. Additionally, within 180 days of the Act's enactment, all credentialed aviation workers requiring fingerprint-based criminal record checks will be continuously vetted through the FBI's Rap Back Service to detect insider threats. Furthermore, within the same timeframe, the Administrator will enhance the Administration's ability to utilize resources from the Department of Homeland Security for insider threat education and mitigation. The Administrator will conduct covert testing of employee inspection operations at airports to measure security effectiveness and provide results to airport operators. Playbook operations for employee physical inspections will be targeted and strategic to enhance security effectiveness. The Administrator will provide testing results and recommendations to airport operators, air carriers, and foreign air carriers. They will also submit an annual report on employee inspection operations at airports for fiscal years 2018 through 2022. Additionally, a centralized database must be established within 180 days. The Administrator will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges for security non-compliance. Reporting mechanisms for airlines and airport operators to submit data and access the database will be determined. Individuals will have a process to challenge their inclusion in the database. The Administrator will establish a national database of individuals with revoked airport badges for security non-compliance. Individuals can challenge their inclusion in the database and have their names removed if mistakenly entered. The Department of Homeland Security leads insider threat coordination efforts at airports, working with other government entities, air carriers, foreign carriers, and airport operators. The Administrator must submit a plan for recurring reviews of IT security controls within 90 days. No additional funds are authorized. No additional funds are authorized for carrying out the requirements of this Act, using amounts otherwise authorized.
